Description: Handle-plate of Attic black-figured pottery colum-krater; sides and underside glazed black. On top, siren to right, head turned back to regard an incised rosette; red for her face, neck, dots on her wing-bow, cover feathers, alternate sickle feathers, and tail; framing lines around.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The handle plate may belong to the same column-krater as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.187.1894, which Bakir has attributed to the Painter of Berlin 1659 (Ressami (1982), Izmir, p. 17).
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 76, no. 252 pl. 56)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 123) (Naukratis 99)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0937)
